APP_ID: Pukekohe High School - Design Problem and Brief
APP_TITLE: Writing a Design Problem, Brief and Specification
APP_SUBTITLE: Learning Assessment - Clear Language, Clear Evidence

ASSESSMENTS.title: Stage 1 – Writing a Design Problem and Brief
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: Task 1

questions.id: Write a Design Problem and Brief
questions.text:
Describe the design problem and write a brief for your project.

In your response, you must:
- clearly explain what the problem or need is
- identify who the stakeholder(s) are
- explain why this is a problem and why it needs to be solved
- describe the context or situation where the problem exists
- explain what the design outcome needs to achieve (do not describe your final solution)
- include any constraints or limitations that will affect the design

Your answer should focus on the need, not the solution, and should guide the rest of your project.
questions.hint:
To PASS, your specification must be written as a clear list of criteria (bullet points or numbered).

Each point should:
• Start with: “The outcome must…” or “It must…”
• Be measurable or testable (include numbers where possible)
• Focus on what it must DO or achieve — NOT what it will look like

A strong specification usually includes criteria for:
1) Function – What must it do? (e.g., The outcome must securely hold 4 textbooks.)
2) User – Who must it work for? (e.g., The outcome must be suitable for Year 9–10 students.)
3) Size – Dimensions or limits (e.g., Must be no larger than 400mm x 300mm.)
4) Materials – What is allowed or restricted (e.g., Must use sustainable timber available in the workshop.)
5) Safety – What risks must be reduced or avoided (e.g., Must have no sharp edges.)
6) Durability – How strong or long-lasting (e.g., Must support at least 10kg without bending.)
7) Cost/Time – Budget or deadline limits (e.g., Must cost under $30 and be completed within 3 weeks.)
8) Sustainability – Waste, reuse, environmental impact.
9) Testing – How you will check success (e.g., It will be tested by loading it with 10kg for 1 minute.)

Avoid vague statements like:
✗ It should look cool.
✗ It should be good quality.
✗ I will make it out of plywood.

Instead, make every point specific and measurable.

questions.text:
Write a specification for your design outcome.

Your specification must:
- be written as a list of clear criteria
- use measurable or testable language
- describe what the outcome must achieve
- include constraints and requirements

Do NOT describe your final solution.
